column1: It’s not limited to the Hamptons: https://ny.eater.com/2020/3/23/21190803/carb…

Most of those people are delivery people. I see them hanging out together on the street. I wouldn't order delivery because those people are likely to bring the virus to you with your food. They spend their down time in groups chatting, they are making deliveries to and interacting with god knows how many people, and go all over the place etc. They seem highly likely to get infected.

People just don't get it sometimes. As the stories of the new virus was starting, I sat down with a friend who told me about 5 minutes into our conversation at a concert, "Oh, I think I'm coming down with a cold." Luckily I didn't get anything. Then there was the story of a woman who walked into the local Spectrum (cable, tv, phone) office late last week who was wearing a hospital bracelet. When she was questioned by the clerk she said that she had just come from the hospital for treatment for the coronavirus. They immediately shut down the office & disinfected everything but what was she thinking?

"They immediately shut down the office & disinfected everything but what was she thinking?" she was simply thinking about herself and nobody else. A lot of people are selfish. There is real concern that the president is considering pulling back on the social distancing against the advice of the medical community. If he does that it is game over. Guess we need a famous NBA player or someone to drop dead over this for it to be taken more seriously by the public.

The rest of us order from restaurants and drive or walk over to the restaurant to pick it up at the front door. This seems safest to me. My Brother-in-law lives in Times Square, so he, his missus, and the dog are about the only one who walk around there nowadays. And he picks things up at the restaurant door, and leaves a 20% tip for the staff.

People in the UK are ignoring advice to self-isolate or keep contact to an absolute minimum. News reports show all of our beach resorts and coastal walks/promenades absolutely mobbed yesterday. Parks were the same and hillwalking, mountaineering resorts were the same. These stupid people are just not getting it.Boris is making a statement at 8.30pm tonight (20 minutes from now) and I fear it will be to advise of total lockdown due to ignorance/disbelief of the advice given non-stop so far.

@5 my understanding is that the UK was letting the virus spread under the theory that people would build up immunity and they could keep it to a level that it wouldn't overwhelm the medical system. Now they are seeing that its not something they can keep in check and are trying to backtrack.
No red259 this is absolutely not the case and I can’t imagine how or where you got that idea. I’m off to watch the PM address to the country now and will post afterwards.
#7 - There were multiple reports (perhaps incorrect?) about a plan to at least partly rely on "herd immunity" https:/…

So, our PM Boris Johnson has just announced a lockdown for at least three weeks. This is largely due to people ignoring the advice to self-isolate, keep a safe distance, stay away from people/public places etc, etc, etc. I feel upset at the view the UK were allowing the virus to spread to build immunity. So not the case as to to laughable and embarrassing.It’s a bit of a nightmare to be honest and none of us know how we will deal with it. No choice really, but I forsee a lot of difficulties.Edited: 4:49 pm, March 23, 2020
@7 Just some examples. It absolutely was the case. https:/…https:/…https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/20…
In the UK there WAS talk of letting the virus spread. This was in the early days. The idea was knocked on the head because this strategy works when there is a vaccine. There's NO vaccine.

As I said, I feel upset at the view the UK were not taking this seriously. The vast majority of us absolutely were/are.Possibly BJ’s delivery of the handling of the crisis was/is different from your leader’s way, but please be assured that the vast majority of us have not seen it the way your links above suggest.

This is terribly scary. He's only 57. But a bunch of morons need their Carbone. Get a life.

red: Is there someone who delivers wine?EVERY Liquor store delivers. I got an email from Garnet that they are now only delivering cases right now. I don't buy alcohol that often maybe once every six weeks or so and like to go and look around the store before picking out what I want, although I do have some wines I am partial to so I could certainly call up and place a specific order. How much would I typically save by buying a case vs buying individual bottles? I don't normally buy in bulk (don't drink it super fast and limited storage area) but if its going to be a few months then maybe it would be worth looking into.
Depending on the store, 10-20% off of a case. Most stores will do a mixed case without an issue.

Re “not just the hamptons” ... can we just acknowledge that such a phrase is a gross mischaracterization of an entire community? Are there arrogant mega rich? Yes. But there are also plenty of regular people. Generous people. Hard working people. Local people. My husband grew up here in the 60s and 70s and we got our own house here 10 years ago. I’m tired of hearing the bs about our community. The place runs on local businesses. They’re hurting. They depend on the summer season and do you really think people will be going to the Hamptons this summer to be going out? And please, forget the puff pieces about all the mega million homes. They are just one part of a very diverse area. Did you know 1/3 of East Hampton is Hispanic? Probably not because that doesn’t get the headlines. That it’s a Sanctuary City? Probably not. And forget the designer stores. They’re just billboards for high end international brands.

The hamptons have a lot of lower income people that live there year round. The rich just come in during the summer. I grew up in a summer town on the shore. The town's population would quadruple during the summertime, but only a small group of us were true locals.Edited: 11:42 pm, March 24, 2020

Huntley, I fully agree with you and have quite a number of friends among the local community in each of the towns. The comment was in reference to another post that contained a quite heinous article about the homeowners who have left the city and gone out east. I think it was in the NYPost, but it was the subject of a lot of comment in this forumThere is nothing wrong w people who own homes to choose to spend time in them now. Others disagree, but if you own a home, pay taxes, etc, then it should be available for you as you choose. And I am quite familiar w the year round nature of the local communities (I’m both very friendly w a number of locals and have dated two or three for extended periods). Note: another one of these class warfare articles will be appearing in The NY Times soon. I was asked to give names of people i know who left to a reporter writing a story on people leaving the city but I declined. I gave them (w my friend’s consent) the name of someone who left for Canada instead.
There is the Shinnecock Nation lands next to Southampton and an African American community outside of Sag Harbor as well.

Risa - I read that post piece. I’m glad to know you didn’t take it seriously!As the Dr (not Fauci, the other dr who’s name escapes me at the moment) said behind the podium, people leaving nyc (like we did) for their houses on Long Island (like we did) need to self quarantine for 14 days (which we’ve been doing for 18 days, so far.)Yesterday the Town of East Hampton issued the same recommendation. We already have many cases here. And just a small hospital. So we are staying home 24/7 for however long it takes until this horrible crisis passes. We’re also very grateful to the usps guy, the fed ex guy, and the ups guy, who have been literal lifelines as we order online to stock the pantry & the freezer. If other people are in the same boat, please give these people a tip. Whatever you can afford. If you go out and shop, please consider doing the same in grocery & drug stores. And if there are small businesses you rely on generally but can’t support now either because they’re closed or for any other reason, most places have set up go fund me campaigns for their employees. Give as generously as you can.

Yes. My friends out there and in Manhattan are all tipping very very generously for the services. I plan on Venmo’ing my hairdresser some cash (as soon as I find out whether I’m getting paid or not. Unclear right now and, well, quite scary). I spoke with one of my restaurant owner friends he has had no trouble getting fresh supplies in sag harbor. And I hear Bobby vans has converted to a meat purveyor in Bridgehampton and packing up for home cooking.I never take those articles seriously. One or two bad actors is not indicative of a whole community.Edited: 10:56 am, March 25, 2020

I guess some situations bring the best in people and others the worse.There was an older lady at a grocery store a few days ago, someone screamed at her for being there as it was dangerous for her. The message was right but the delivery of said message was all wrong. The lady was there because she had no one to help and started crying. Fortunately, someone came to her rescue, gave her phone number and offered to do errands for the older lady.

Risa - yes, restaurants and other take out food businesses are really stepping up out here with curbside and/or delivery. And I’m sure we will occasionally take them up on it! But it’s not financially sustainable for many people to eat this way regularly, and it’s not our thing in any case. My husband spent 3.5 hrs going from store to store looking for things when we first got here. He was extremely frustrated.  And that was before the shelves at some groceries went empty. I don’t actually know how the stores out here are this week. But with more and niece NYC residents landing here all thev time ...mThe good news for us is that I love to cook. But the time suck has been finding the right online sources for various things. MI’m dealing w a resp virus (not covid) that I picked up in India 8 weeks ago (!) so I’m compromised. I’m also 63. So it’s not smart for either my husband or I to shop around town. Ive recently started a daily Instagram of what I make for dinner every night. @CiaoBellaFina (my jewelry line account.). Sadly I left almost all my jewelry materials and all my finished product in NYC because we didn’t have room in the car for it & thought at that time that my husband would be back in a few days to load up that and other overflow. That turned out to be a bad idea. So I’m expressing myself in the kitchen instead. It’s been very rewarding. I’m trying new things based on what I have in the pantry & the freezer. So far so good lol. Tonight’s dinner is home made 7 grain bread, fish I got from Alaska sautéed with lemon & capers, and a simple stir fry vegetable from a bag of same from Trader Joe’s that I brought from our nyc freezer. To all my friends as well as people I don’t know who are still in NYC, we think about you constantly. We love our city. And we’re grateful to every single person on the front lines, and to gov Cuomo, who is doing a fantastic job, demonstrating competence, straight talk & empathy every single day.

You're doing the right thing. I understand why people are leaving. While I have friends in Manhattan who insist that they are fine going on long "socially distant" walks, it makes me nervous. Between elevators and door handles, etc etc, there are too many land mines to risk going outside. At least out there, you have a little space to be outside. A friend of mine in DC is experiencing chills, usually the first sign of "it." She has a dog and has been doing long dog walks, and probably got exposed that way. It's very scary. I'm staying inside. Thankful for my yoga mat and Deepak Chopra meditations.

A couple of points regarding the UK and ‘herd immunity’.Firstly there is no vaccine and there’s no prospect of one soon. There may never be a vaccine - there are other viral illnesses that have no vaccine (the common cold for instance). Most viral illnesses are mitigated by ‘herd immunity’ to some extent.But the issue with Covid 19 is not only is it more infectious than (say) ‘flu, it’s also more deadly. The effect is that with a highly infectious deadly disease healthcare systems get overwhelmed quickly and when that happens people who would ordinarily recover can’t get treatment and die. These need not be Covid 19 sufferers but anyone who needs a high dependency hospital bed or the staff with the skills.The UK number crunchers reckoned more than 500,000 additional deaths (more than WW2, more than Hiroshima and Nagasaki combined) within a few months. So it became obvious the only viable tactic was to slow the spread and reduce the peak demand on hospital beds.It may be the total numbers infected will be unchanged, but by reducing the peak the availability of the healthcare system to respond is improved and the death count reduced. After a while (months hopefully) sufficient people will have been infected and have developed immunity so although the disease may rumble on the hospitals will be able to cope. Maybe a vaccine will turn up but the strategy doesn’t rely on it.And yes Boris appears as a bit bumbling and on the edge of losing control - it’s an act! Nicola Sturgeons act is very different, but successful politicians all have a style that works for them.

IMO it's not necessarily the act of going to an alternate location.It's whether you do so responsibly.Arriving and behaving like locusts when the local stores (esp. in a location in with a "season") when they would not have anticipated increased demand and been able to increase stocks is inappropriate.Knowingly traveling with test results pending/confirmed and/or symptoms of active disease and then showing up at a smaller hospital is even more wrongEdited: 2:01 pm, March 25, 2020

Just a shout-out to my fellow New Yorkers. Hope everyone is hanging in there. Big big big shout-out to medical professionals, EMS, Police, Fire, and everyone who is considered essential personnel. I have been holed up in my studio apartment, the one that I got thinking “Well, it’s tiny but I won’t be spending much time here.” I have been doing fine, thank God. I got supplies a few weeks ago and have limited going out to absolute essential trips. Last week I had to go in to work and, not wanting to take the subway, I rented a Citibike. I sanitized it of course, had gloves on, my own helmet. If. You are in the city and able to do this, I highly highly recommend renting one of these bikes and enjoying the relative lack of traffic. It was surreal pedaling through Herald Square and Times Square and crossing over those wide avenues with only random cars and buses to dodge. If you are stressed out or getting cabin fever, I highly recommend. Just be sure to disinfect the bike and take care while renting it, using the touch pads with a tissue, gloves or wiping everything with disinfectant.

Howard, I really don't think you understand the dynamics at all. The "rich people" come in and buy properties at inflated prices, which then drives up the property taxes for everyone, not just the person who sold that property, and forces the people who have lived there for generations to leave. My husband grew up in a small village by the ocean with dirt roads, local fishermen and small houses. In the past fifteen years, that village has become a mecca for people with more money than taste. They buy, tear down the houses and build McMansions. No lobstermen live there any more and most houses are owned by people "from away." His mother has managed to hang on. When we dropped off her groceries today, almost all of the license plates were from out of state and had arrived in the past week. Are they sick? Do they plan to self-quarantine for 14 days as requested by our governor? Did they bring their own supplies so I don't have to compete with even more people for some #$%@ toilet paper? Is there enough room in our hospitals and do they even have a primary care doctor here?You may feel we made a deal with the devil, but the devil just showed up and took over.

Tourists brought prosperity to an Idaho ski valley. They also brought covid-19.https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/tour…"Now the valley is a coronavirus hot spot, registering one of the highest infection rates per capita in the country. With 192 cases in a county of just 22,000 people — including two deaths — the share of the population testing positive is greater than even in New York City.The impact has been dramatic: The small hospital in Ketchum, the region’s hub, has partially shut down after four of its seven emergency doctors were quarantined. Patients are being ferried to facilities hours away. The fire department is relying on fresh-faced volunteers, trained in a day, to drive ambulances.""Along with a handful of other ski hubs in the western United States, the Wood River Valley — whose population density is about 3,000 times less than New York City’s — offers a preview of what happens when the novel coronavirus escapes cities and attacks rural America."

Re 292 and 293: I think there is a lot of confusion about what is and is not dangerous behavior. While it's true you can't assume someone is spreading the virus unless they have been tested, some (like the PM of New Zealand) take the approach, for now, to stamp out virus (which is what they are trying to do there) we all need to assume we are carriers, no matter how good we feel -- therefore, stay inside, wash hands/sanitize both BEFORE and after going out, etc. (And even if you HAVE been tested, just because you were negative last week doesn't mean you're negative this week).The thing about second and third homeowners retreating to their country properties is it is perceived by locals as possibly straining local services (not to mention importing plague from the big bad city) -- whether small community hospitals or local supermarkets and gas stations. Of course, it is true that the second and third homeowners are also taxpayers and have a right to be there. However, those taxes would likely be higher for everyone if local government needed to assume services were going to be provided year round to a larger population. The hospitals, regardless of who funds them, would likely be operated and staffed differently if they knew they would be serving a larger population. Many small community hospitals in resort areas bring in temporary docs and nurses during normal "high" seasons, have more calls by specialists from regional medical centers in "high" season, etc. So having a whole bunch of people suddenly move in during the off season can at least temporarily strain services. It's nothing that can't be fixed by having supermarket and gas stations order more, or a tax hike next year, or scrambling for more hospital help now, but in the meantime it can be unpleasant for the folks already there.Some people are really getting carried away by something about which they knew practically nothing a month ago. Yesterday some woman on my neighborhood site was mouthing off about how disgusting it was for people to be walking around outside without masks. Agree with Kaye in 470.For anyone genuinely concerned about actual safety under normal circumstances (that is, when tourists return):"I see women walking alone at night ALL the time. Under normal circumstances with basic commonsense NYC is safe."I grew up not far from Manhattan, but moved here after college when I was 21. During the 80s, there were some rougher spots, like Amsterdam Ave in the high 80s-90s, which were a little dicey. I was pickpocketed on subways and buses during that period from time to time. Since then, the city is fine. I take the subway home late at night (2AM?) by myself with no concern. I walk home after 11 with no concern. My decision to take a taxi instead of the subway has to do with (a) if it's late and there will be a 20 minute wait for a subway and I just want to get home already or (b) I'm wearing very high heels and in a place that is more than a 10 minute walk to a subway and it's late and I'm tired. Otherwise, I have left black tie events at Cipriani after 11 or 12 at night and gotten right on the subway at 42nd next to the entrance. No concern whatsoever. No concern walking home from the subway. I can't speak for the safety of every spot in the 5 boroughs of NYC. But I have zero, absolutely ZERO concern about being a single woman in Manhattan alone at night moving around in any locale that would be likely for a reasonable tourist to be. That's 37 years of continuous living in Manhattan on the UWS (W 90s), UES (East 60ths) and in FiDi. And I've walked home from let's say, Pastis to FiDi, whenever the weather is good (and the shoes aren't stilettos, but just wedges). And that's why I love NYC.Edited: 2:27 pm, April 17, 2020

How do you pay for it? That’s just one example. Then they have to decide who goes back to work, does everyone? Is it by industry or is it by risk factor? #640, #644The Ontario Ministry of Health has been providing the public with daily updated epidemiological summaries, since at least mid-March in the form of PDF files that one could download. I have kept the occasional one.Early on the epidemiological summaries included the breakdown in the number of cases in the province based on history of travel vs locally acquired. Over time the % of travel related cases decreased compared to community acquired cases; what didn’t decrease was the number of cases with a history of travel to the US compared to other countries. We were actually booked to travel to Palm Springs in March, but cancelled our trip based on the information being published by the Ministry of Health at the time. We were concerned about getting sick while in Palm Springs and not being able to return home when planned, or even if we didn’t get sick while in the US having to go into quarantine for 14 days on returning home to Canada.The earliest daily summary that I kept was actually for March 31st, which I downloaded at the time to share with someone who was still claiming travel between Canada and China as a major source of local infection—the Toronto area actually has the largest concentration of Chinese immigrants in North America, if not the world—and I wanted to show them that that idea was not at all accurate!These are the numbers for the top 10 travel locations from Appendix A of that 11 page March 31st summary (moh-covid-19-report-en-2020-03-31): “Confirmed cases (n=567) of COVID-19 with travel history* by location: Ontario, January 15, 2020 to March 31, 2020”United States 168 (cases)United Kingdom 61Cruise 48Germany 24Spain 21Mexico 20Austria 19Iran 17Philippines 15France 14Italy ranked 18th, with 5 cases, and China ranked 21st with only 4 cases related to travel from mid-January until the end of March 2020..The above information is in keeping with the NYC data showing that Flushing was actually fairly unaffected by COVID-19 around that same time period, as well as news items reporting the majority of NYS infections had originated in Europe, not China: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020…Here is a link to our MOH website but I don’t know how to get links to specific previous daily epidemiological summaries, https:/…section-0 . If you look at today’s summary you’ll see that the areas of Ontario with the largest “rate” of confirmed cases is actually at the site of border crossings between Ontario and New York State (Figure 5 on page 9 of today’s summary).Edited: 12:39 pm, April 22, 2020

** areas of Ontario with the largest “rate” of confirmed cases is actually at the site of border crossings between Ontario and New York State. **How many of those 168 U.S. cases between Jan. 15- Mar. 31 were "initial" cases? You can't prove that. I guess Canada should have closed its borders much earlier than it did.We were supposed to be having a wonderful time in Turks and Caicos from 3/23 -4/1. We wait all year for that vacation. I rescheduled for December. Hopefully things will be sane by then. I don't blame my President, I blame China, WHO and the CDC for mucking things up.

I worry in particular about, and pray especially for, those that may not have the safety nets they need to help them get through this crisis.I’ve been thinking about health coverage during this pandemic: if employees have been furloughed do they continue to be covered by their insurance plan, assuming it was employer sponsored to begin with. 1004 - There's a difference depending on if you are furloughed or laid off. It can also vary depending on where you livehttps://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/31/how-to-keep-…Co-pays and out of pocket expenses can be an issue even in "normal" timesEdited: 5:53 pm, May 05, 2020

Even if ex-employees are not entitled to medical coverage, SOME employers are continuing it for several months because of the crisis.Also note that in US there is federal law called COBRA that gives certain people (former employees, former spouses, widows) who would otherwise have lost health coverage (and that includes all medical, dental, vision, etc) the right to continue coverage for period specified in law as long as they pay full premium -- both employer and employee shares -- plus small admin fee. For terminated employees I believe max period is 18 months. Although employee has to pay full cost, this is generally less expensive than buying on open market, with better benefits. When I did COBRA several yrs ago my premium was around $700 a month and included dental. When it ended and I had to go on an individual plan premium was about $1400 a month and did not include dental. BY the time I turned 65 and qualified for Medicare my premiums had gone up to $1800 a month (tho was a comprehensive plan with both in and out of network benefits, low copays, deductibles, etc.). I would have to read law to know if COBRA distinguishes between furloughed and terminated employees. May just boil down to whether the event results in loss of employer coverage.Edited: 6:33 pm, May 05, 2020
Hospitals are losing money but don't worry big insurance companies are getting paid.https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/05/hospitals-lo…

Also note that not all employers provide medical coverage to begin with -- many, esp smaller ones, can't afford it, so if employees had no employer-sponsored covg to begin with, certainly wouldn't have any after being terminated.
*** Also note that not all employers provide medical coverage to begin with***Part time jobs typically don’t offer coverage.
In the last few years, companies large and small finally started calling health plans what they are - "high deductible".
Not to mention self employed people pay for their own coverage and if they are shutdown they have no income coming in to pay premiums.

I'm on furlough but still have my health insurance. I usually have a premium deducted from my pay check but I don't have to pay that while I am on furlough (I don't know if I will have to make that up when I go back to work - hope not).Edited: 8:04 pm, May 05, 2020

One eight-year Cargill veteran, who calls herself Anabel, says she worked the entire week of March 16 while sick. Anabel got so weak she could hardly stand up, but she didn’t leave because she didn’t want points on her record from unexcused absences. “Every time I coughed, there was someone in front of me and next to me,” says Anabel, who tested positive for Covid-19 on March 24. “All my co-workers got sick.”

Even If You're Trying To Avoid Grubhub By Calling Your Favorite Restaurant Directly, Grubhub Could Still Be Charging It A Feehttps://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/venessa…Here’s how phone fees work: Grubhub (which also owns Seamless, MenuPages, Tapingo, and LevelUp) generates a unique phone number for each restaurant on its platform; it appears on the restaurant’s Grubhub or Seamless page and redirects to the restaurant's own phone line (a restaurant cannot list its own phone number on its Grubhub or Seamless page). The redirect number can also appear higher in Google search results (including the Google panel for that business) than the restaurant’s own line. This leads some customers to call it even if they don’t intend to use Grubhub. Some restaurant owners have also raised this concern about Yelp, which lists Grubhub numbers, according to Vice.

Thanks Kaye for the interesting and relevant info about ordering and possibly triggering a fee when you contact the restaurant directly. I like to order and pick up myself, so I always try to be aware of situations like that which can be avoided.

My husband had heart surgery and the mask does cause him to stop in the middle of a leisure walk to catch his breath. The obstruction caused by a mask can also cause his heart beat to increase. We have to walk with a monitor to ensure it is within acceptable range. If he did not wear a mask this would not be an issue. But, for him it is not a case of not being able to wear a mask. @1343 - While this article has some relevance I think the key question here is, is it sensible for a world leader to state this information publicly? There is still research going on to establish if this drug, in combination with 2 others can prevent people with COVID-19 from becoming seriously ill. There have also been studies suggesting it could actually be dangerous. Nobody, as far as I'm aware has suggested there are benefits to taking it as a preemptive measure if you have no symptoms. It's also widely accepted that this, and other anti-malarial drugs can have some pretty serious side-effects. Let's also not forget the fact that there are people with existing chronic illnesses that rely on these drugs to manage their own conditions.If his doctor is happy to prescribe then fine, that's up to him and the patient. However I would be very keen to know what, if any benefit sharing this information would have? When you know you have influence over millions of people and many will likely now want to do the same, would it not be sensible to keep that information to yourself unless you can be 100% sure that the impact will be a positive one?

I thought the third link in post 1419 was particularly helpful because it gives good practical advice for those individuals who really should be wearing masks for their own protection because of underlying health problems like asthma and COPD. Let’s face it, even if they stay home as much as possible there will be occasions that they will have to leave their home, even if it is just for an assessment with the physician who normally monitors their health problems.IMO, some of the current mindset, that wearing a mask to protect yourself doesn’t help, was triggered early on, both in the US and Canada, because there was such a shortage of masks while the number of cases out in the community was thought to be low; at that time it was felt that the risk to the average person out in public was low so individuals were encouraged to NOT wear masks in order to prevent mask hoarding by the public, similar to what was seen with toilet paper, in order to make available as many masks as possible for the service providers who needed them. Often we were told that wearing a mask actually increased our risk, because we would become less vigilant and less likely to use the other preventative measures of social distancing along with frequent proper handwashing.As it became obvious that the number of cases in the community was higher than previously thought, and that many cases were actually asymptomatic, the message started to shift towards encouraging everyone to wear a mask. Aside from the issue that the pandemic was promoted as a hoax in some circles—which hasn’t helped—I believe the mixed messaging has confused many people who genuinely want to do the right thing. If these individuals had been told to wear home made masks, or bandannas, from the start there might be less resistance at this time.This is an unprecedented event in our collective lives, and mistakes were made by those who we thought should have known better. As they learn more, we need to learn from them, in order to keep each other, and in the long run ourselves as well as those we love, safe and well.Edit: I plan on wearing a mask to protect others and I hope others will wear a mask so that my family stays well.Edited: 8:29 pm, May 21, 2020

“I wear a mask to protect others and glasses to protect my eyes.”I also wear glasses, this predates COVID-19, and like others I found that my glasses would fog up, which was particularly annoying when I was shopping. I have now started using a paper clip to help with this annoyance! Before leaving home I straighten out a small paper clip and tape it, using good quality clear shipping tape, to the inside of my mask along the top edge of the mask. When I put the mask on, I push on the paper clip wire so that it fits snugly against my nasal bridge, which in turn stops my breath from escaping through the top of my mask, and that actually helps decrease the amount of fogging on my glasses!I use cheaper quality paper clips because the wire is thinner and bends easily, but a piece of any fine gauge wire should work. I’ve even thought of taping a twist tie to the inside of my mask but I haven’t tried that yet. I did find that regular scotch tape didn’t adhere well but clear shipping tape does; a thin strip of duct tape might work too. The shipping tape is actually a bit too wide so I cut it in half, lengthwise, and use only one piece. If you decide to try this, make sure that the piece of tape is long enough to cover the ends of the paper clip, or wire, so that they don’t rub on your face, another reason to use finer gauge paper clips or wire. Remember to remove the wire before washing the mask and make sure it’s dry before using it again :)

#145214 days is the “magic number” needs to be used in context. This usually refers to the incubation period, i.e. how long it can take for someone to develop the infection once they have been exposed. If they have not shown symptoms during that time they are considered clear, but we now know that without testing they may in fact be infectious only asymptomatic. Without testing being done on everyone those cases will get missed.An asymptomatic person who is still infected after 14 days can continue to spread the infection to others; that new group of infected people may contain individuals who themselves have mild cases and escape attention, or those who get quite sick and become a statistic by being tested or admitted to hospital. Just because they’re not showing up yet, doesn’t mean they won’t in another week or two. If you recall, it appears that those who require hospitalization because of COVID-19 usually don’t need it right away; their symptoms may be mild initially, build up over 7-10 days, and when they start feeling weak, short of breath, etc that’s when they show up in hospital. A better time frame for assessing the success of reopening, without an immediate uptake being seen, and in the absence of random testing of “healthy” people, will actually be 3-4 weeks at least.Georgia’s Department of Public Health website, https:/…covid-19-daily-status-report , doesn’t show the timing of their tests, so they may not be doing any random testing currently and only test those who show up in hospital for confirmation. I do hope—for everyone’s sake—that there will not be a resurgence of cases, but I do think it’s too early to say that the re-opening has been successful.#1454Again, that “decreasing” rolling seven-day average may be a reflection of decreased testing being carried out and not a true decrease in cases. Georgia doesn’t appear to report anywhere how many tests have been done on a daily basis in the last month compared to before the re-opening.

“ For ANY state, at least HALF the severe cases from COVID are in nursing homes and long term care facilities.While that may be true, and I have no reason to not believe that considering 80% of COVID-19 deaths in Canada have been in nursing homes, two important points should be kept in mind when advocating to reopen fully:1. The majority of seniors across the US are not living “in nursing homes and long term care facilities” so there is a large part of that group that will be at increased risk of getting sick and dying if everything opens up again. They already sacrificed a lot in their lifetime so that we could have the lifestyles that we now enjoy. How we treat them now will serve as an example to younger generations of how they should treat us down the road. In addition, one of the main reasons that I hear expressed as to why a single payer health care system is not welcome by many is that the elderly will be euthanized in order to cut costs (not true imo)! However, it seems to me that in fact the countries with universal coverage are the ones that are trying hardest to protect those same seniors that live among us in our communities, regardless of the sacrifices we need to make. This was witnessed in countries like Italy, Spain, ... and I see it happening in Canada as well.2. Apart from the fact that nursing homes are filled with vulnerable individuals, they’re also a form of a mini-community that includes relatively young staff, and that younger group of individuals have also shown a greater risk of getting sick with many dying. This should make all of us stop and think what would have happened if measures that were taken to distance people in our communities had not taken place: most likely there would have been the same widespread devastation that took place in our nursing homes.

#1459Thank you for posting those results!Some statements in that article need further clarification before anyone can judge their true significance:1. “668 new cases of the coronavirus [reported] Sunday afternoon, bringing the cumulative total to 42,838.” => That actually represents a 1.7 % increase in cases. It doesn’t say over what time frame, so for all we know that could have been over a period of just a day or two.2. “The number of currently hospitalized patients continues to fall. On Tuesday, 986 current hospitalizations marked the lowest number of COVID-19 positive patients hospitalized since hospitals started reporting data to the Georgia Emergency Management and Homeland Security Agency on April 8. Those record lows changed to 959 on Wednesday, 919 on Thursday, 889 on Friday and 848 since Saturday.” => For these numbers to be meaningful they need to indicate when these people were admitted to hospital; this trend may just reflect the gradual health improvement in patients that were infected before the re-opening occurred and the fact that there weren’t relatively new cases being admitted (the later reflecting that the shutdown was helping!)3. “cumulative hospitalizations increased by 28 from Saturday to Sunday afternoon.” So 28 people were sick enough to be admitted in ONE day => Isn’t that a reflection that there are more cases popping up in the community and shouldn’t this be a cause for concern?4. “As of 1 p.m. Sunday, there have been 481,954 tests completed, an increase of 28,417 since Saturday. Approximately 8.9 percent of molecular and serological tests statewide have come back positive overall.” => Only molecular tests are accurate for diagnosing new cases, how many of the 28,417 were molecular type tests? Without that information, this actually doesn’t tell us anything about what is going on, one way or another. If they were all serological tests, what breakdown of antibody type was found? If they were overwhelmingly IgG type then these individuals are actually not recent cases but fully recovered cases that were infected more than 6 weeks ago. That figure of 28,417 may look good on paper, or in a article, but only to those who don’t understand what they’re reading, imho. But then again what do I know?

#1463That phrase has been used by him to scare people i.e. He’s insinuating that those who favour/introduce a lockdown are not planning to open up again, where in reality their plan is to open up once it’s safe to do so.

DiBlasio and Cuomo didn't kill thousands by failing to properly use the Comfort and the Javits Center. They didn't use those places because in the end they apparently had enough space in hospitals. In other words,somebody over-estimated their possible need for beds and/or the skill sets of those facilities. I don't believe the Comfort was ever intended for COVID patients. Its specialty is apparently combat wounds, so they intended to use it for normal gunshot sounds, stabbings, etc, but those didn't materialize in a much quieter city. The Javits Center was intended for people w/milder COVID symptoms, and though they had some of those, it was not in numbers expected. But neither facility was prepared for seriously ill COVID patients.If any of those deaths are their responsibility, it is more likely because they were not prepared and acted too late. It is possible they were waiting for the federal government to provide some guidance/leadership, but if there is one thing local and state officials have learned from this catastrophe it's that you can't count on the federal government for leadership. I think one smart thing Cuomo did was set up that consortium with 6 other eastern states to acquire, store and share supplies. I suspect this will come in handy in future disasters when the national government fails..

rjrGreat points. Some people don't get the point that those people would have had another 10 years or more if not for Cuomo's despicable, careless handling of our elderly. Yeah, we're all gonna die one day. But it doesn't have to be today because of idiotic bureaucracy.

#1590 I realize Cuomo is getting a pass but if the federal government had taken the lead on this, hadn't shut up that doctor at the CDC who tried to get the word out (Messonier, the one who finally went against orders & had conference call w/press in late Feb that made clear what we faced; I couldn't believe my ears) and simply ordered states to take action a couple weeks before most of them did (not to mention help coordinate provisioning by professionals instead of by president's son in law and his frat bros) many lives could have been saved. I have read that starting the lockdown just a week or so earlier in NYC could have saved 50% of the fatalities here. It really would have helped if the pres, instead of denying advice of his own experts, denying there was a problem & obsessing over his ratings could have ordered everyone to prepare.To be honest, I was slowly stocking up on supplies in early-mid Feb based on what I had been reading in the NY Times since early Jan.I also think it's important to watch out for the attitude that "it's just a bunch of old nursing home people who should have died a long time ago/were costing us too much/got more than their fare share of real estate gains," etc., etc.Everyone's life has value, and from what I have heard this is an awful death full of suffering you wouldn't wish on any sentient being. And a lot of the older victims were not "nursing home people" on the verge of death. They were active people living in their own homes and contributing to their communities and families. Then there is a huge group in the middle (that is, between the asymptomatic 20-somethings and the nursing home crowd). These are people, often in 30s to 60s, who survived but who had very serious cases with long hospital stays and may have suffered life-altering after-effects that will change their lives forever -- possibly requiring, in addition to major lifestyle changes, ongoing medical monitoring & care/expense, rehabilitation, career changes or disability benefits, organ transplants and who knows what else. Personally, I would like to avoid having anything to do with any of that stuff. I am not a wealthy person and know there are not enough insurance benefits on earth to cover those types of largely post-hospital expenses.
I forgot to say “Thank You”

The proper way to address the country and try to calm the situation (statement of Joe Biden):These last few days have laid bare that we are a nation furious at injustice. Every person of conscience can understand the rawness of the trauma people of color experience in this country, from the daily indignities to the extreme violence, like the horrific killing of George Floyd.Protesting such brutality is right and necessary. It’s an utterly American response. But burning down communities and needless destruction is not. Violence that endangers lives is not. Violence that guts and shutters businesses that serve the community is not.The act of protesting should never be allowed to overshadow the reason we protest. It should not drive people away from the just cause that protest is meant to advance.I know that there are people all across this country who are suffering tonight. Suffering the loss of a loved one to intolerable circumstances, like the Floyd family, or to the virus that is still gripping our nation. Suffering economic hardships, whether due to COVID-19 or entrenched inequalities in our system. And I know that a grief that dark and deep may at times feel too heavy to bear.I know.And I also know that the only way to bear it is to turn all that anguish to purpose. So tonight, I ask all of America to join me — not in denying our pain or covering it over — but using it to compel our nation across this turbulent threshold into the next phase of progress, inclusion, and opportunity for our great democracy.We are a nation in pain, but we must not allow this pain to destroy us. We are a nation enraged, but we cannot allow our rage to consume us. We are a nation exhausted, but we will not allow our exhaustion to defeat us.As President, I will help lead this conversation — and more importantly, I will listen. I will keep the commitment I made to George’s brother, Philonise, that George will not just be a hashtag. We must and will get to a place where everyone, regardless of race, believes that “to protect and serve” means to protect and serve them. Only by standing together will we rise stronger than before. More equal, more just, more hopeful — and that much closer to our more perfect union.Please stay safe. Please take care of each other.Edited: 4:01 pm, May 31, 2020

A friend of mine wrote this. He is one of the kindest and friendliest people I know. He wrote this a few weeks ago before all of this. This is a successful adult man with with multiple degrees including one from Harvard and still this is how he is made to feel in this country:"Will my new phone get me killed?"That was the thought that I had when I discovered that my new phone didn't have a headphone jack. You see, I take long walks 5 days per week as part of my ongoing therapy for a traumatic back injury. I depend, as so many folks do, on listening to my fitness playlist to get me through my workouts. However, I'm not like most folks that I see on my daily peramubulations. I'm a moderately large, bearded, Black man, and I am never allowed to forget that fact. I don't have the luxury of disappearing into the background, or losing myself in a trance while traveling through time and space. I am forced to be hyper-vigilant, to be aware of the threat that I pose simply by existing.Which brings me back to my phone.My old phone was great. It had lots of features, not the least important was a physical headphone jack. Why was that important? So that my high-visibility hot pink headphones could provide a visual signal that I wasn't striding towards you menacingly while "ignoring your verbal commands." Clearly anyone wearing my usual workout gear, high vis, fluorescent, *conspicuous*, wasn't fitting a description. These are the subtle yet meaningful ways that folks who look like me, who mass as much as I do, who absorb visible light in a fashion more pronounced than others, navigate our way through this world.And it's why I looked at my new, top-of-the-line, premium phone with concern.You see, when I purchased this phone from a salesman who looked like me, whose skin tone was so similar to mine, in the camaraderie of our exchange, it never occurred to me to inquire whether the security features of this premium device also included protection from the flinch; protection from "the look;" protection from the "are you listening to me", hand hovering near a holster, jaw tightening, threat-level raising, another #sayhisname moment only a moment away...Is that too much to ask for from any device? I guess so, because the real truth is that those pink headphones were not a bulletproof vest. They weren't Kevlar and ceramic plated body armor. They were an illusory protection at best, because the answer to my question "Will my new phone get me killed?" is simple. My phone won't get me killed,My country will.
Thank you for your posts, nycforever and red
